answers.title: the Difference between Eager Initialization and Lazy Initialization in Singleton Pattern
answers.body:
"... It is said that the difference between those two ways is that EagerSingleton initializes early during class loading process, and LazySingleton initializes late when it is first used. ..."

Correct, the EagerSingleton class will instantiate the instance field during the class initialization.
Whereas, the LazySingleton class will wait for the getInstance method to be called.

"... I can't see the timing difference because both them have private constructors, which means that you can't create an instance by new and let it without using (which can see the timing difference). ..."

You can utilize the class initialization block to evaluate the fields.

Consider the following.

public class EagerSingleton {
    private static final EagerSingleton instance = new EagerSingleton();

    static {
        System.out.println("EagerSingleton instantiated");
    }

    private EagerSingleton() {
    }

    public static EagerSingleton getInstance() {
        System.out.println("EagerSingleton returned instance");
        return instance;
    }
}

public class LazySingleton {
    private static LazySingleton instance;

    static {
        System.out.println("LazySingleton not instantiated");
    }

    private LazySingleton() {
    }

    public static synchronized LazySingleton getInstance() {
        System.out.println("LazySingleton checking instance");
        if (instance == null) {
            System.out.println("LazySingleton instance assigned");
            instance = new LazySingleton();
        }
        System.out.println("LazySingleton returned instance");
        return instance;
    }
}

Now, create 2 EagerSingleton and 2 LazySingleton objects.

System.out.println("e1");
EagerSingleton e1 = EagerSingleton.getInstance();
System.out.printf("%nl1%n");
LazySingleton l1 = LazySingleton.getInstance();
System.out.printf("%ne2%n");
EagerSingleton e2 = EagerSingleton.getInstance();
System.out.printf("%nl2%n");
LazySingleton l2 = LazySingleton.getInstance();

Output

e1
EagerSingleton instantiated
EagerSingleton returned instance

l1
LazySingleton not instantiated
LazySingleton checking instance
LazySingleton instance assigned
LazySingleton returned instance

e2
EagerSingleton returned instance

l2
LazySingleton checking instance
LazySingleton returned instance

items.title: the Difference between Eager Initialization and Lazy Initialization in Singleton Pattern
items.body:
I find two different ways to implement a singleton pattern, they are Lazy Initialization and Eager Initialization. and the code is:

public class EagerSingleton {
    private static final EagerSingleton instance = new EagerSingleton();

    private EagerSingleton() {
    }

    public static EagerSingleton getInstance() {
        return instance;
    }
}

and:

public class LazySingleton {
    private static LazySingleton instance;

    private LazySingleton() {
    }

    public static synchronized LazySingleton getInstance() {
        if (instance == null) {
            instance = new LazySingleton();
        }
        return instance;
    }
}

It is said that the difference between those two ways is that EagerSingleton initializes early during class loading process, and LazySingleton initializes late when it is first used. But I can't see the timing difference because both them have private constructors, which means that you can't create an instance by new and let it without using (which can see the timing difference). The only way is to use the getInstance() method. So when you use this method, the class loading process and getInstance() both happen at this time. So it seems that they are not different.

Can someone explain the difference in this example?

comments.body_markdown: You can use jpackage, it is simpler for the user but more difficult for you the developer.  Alternately, you can use jlink via the [maven-javafx-plugin](https://github.com/openjfx/javafx-maven-plugin#javafxjlink-options) to create a zipped image, as long as your app and all its dependencies are fully modular.  That is easy for you and easy enough for the customer, (they unzip the distribution and run the bundled shell script).  It will only work on one target OS/architecture, unless you build on multiple machines, but that might be OK depending on app and userbase.

items.title: OpenAPI Swagger Link on Spring Boot 2 Erroring Not Found when it redirects
items.body:
I have a spring boot 2 java application with adding the swagger OpenAPI. I have added the dependency of:

            // Swagger
            "io.swagger.core.v3:swagger-models:2.2.9",
            "org.springdoc:springdoc-openapi-ui:1.7.0",

And I have the following class to configure the bean:

@Configuration
@Order(Ordered.HIGHEST_PRECEDENCE)
public class SwaggerConfig {

    private final ExodusConfig exodusConfig;

    /**
     * Constructor
     *
     * @param exodusConfig The config
     */
    public SwaggerConfig(ExodusConfig exodusConfig) {
        this.exodusConfig = exodusConfig;
    }

    /**
     * Create Open API bean for use
     *
     * @return The created bean
     */
    @Bean
    public OpenAPI customOpenApi() {
        ExodusConfigSwaggerApp swagger = setDefaults();
        OpenAPI openApi = Optional.ofNullable(swagger)
                .filter(ExodusConfigSwaggerApp::isEnabled)
                .map(this::buildOpenApi)
                .orElse(null);
        return openApi;
    }

    /**
     * Build the contact object
     *
     * @param swagger The swagger config data
     *
     * @return The create object
     */
    private static Contact buildContactObject(ExodusConfigSwaggerApp swagger) {
        Contact contact = new Contact();
        contact.setName(swagger.getContactName());
        contact.setEmail(swagger.getContactEmail());
        contact.setUrl(swagger.getContacturl());
        return contact;
    }

    /**
     * Build description
     *
     * @param swagger The swagger config data
     *
     * @return The description string
     */
    private static String buildDescription(ExodusConfigSwaggerApp swagger) {
        return swagger.getApm() + " : " + swagger.getDescription();
    }

    /**
     * Build external docs
     *
     * @param swagger The swagger config data
     *
     * @return The created docs
     */
    private static ExternalDocumentation buildExternalDocs(ExodusConfigSwaggerApp swagger) {
        return (new ExternalDocumentation())
                .description("Confluence Documentation")
                .url(swagger.getConfluencePage());
    }

    /**
     * Build license
     *
     * @param swagger The swagger config data
     *
     * @return The created license
     */
    private static License buildLicense(ExodusConfigSwaggerApp swagger) {
        return (new License())
                .name(swagger.getPorttype() + " : " + swagger.getServicekey())
                .url("http://springdoc.org");
    }

    /**
     * Build Title
     *
     * @param swagger The swagger config data
     *
     * @return The title string
     */
    private static String buildTitle(ExodusConfigSwaggerApp swagger) {
        return swagger.getVendor() + " : " + swagger.getName();
    }

    /**
     * Build version
     *
     * @param swagger The swagger config data
     *
     * @return The version
     */
    private static String buildVersion(ExodusConfigSwaggerApp swagger) {
        return swagger.getVersion();
    }

    /**
     * Build components of the api
     *
     * @return The components
     */
    private Components buildComponents(ExodusConfigSwaggerApp swagger) {
        Components securitySchemaType = new Components();
        if (!swagger.getAuthorizationType().equalsIgnoreCase("BEARER")) {
            securitySchemaType.addSecuritySchemes(swagger.getAuthorizationType() + "-Token",
                    (new SecurityScheme())
                            .type(SecurityScheme.Type.APIKEY)
                            .in(SecurityScheme.In.HEADER)
                            .name("Authorization"));
        } else {
            securitySchemaType.addSecuritySchemes("Bearer-Token",
                    (new SecurityScheme())
                            .type(SecurityScheme.Type.HTTP)
                            .scheme("bearer")
                            .bearerFormat("JWT"));
        }
        return securitySchemaType;
    }

    /**
     * Build the open api object
     *
     * @param swagger The swagger config data
     *
     * @return The created api
     */
    private OpenAPI buildOpenApi(ExodusConfigSwaggerApp swagger) {
        OpenAPI openAPI;
        openAPI = new OpenAPI();
        openAPI.info((new Info())
                .title(buildTitle(swagger))
                .description(buildDescription(swagger))
                .version(buildVersion(swagger))
                .contact(buildContactObject(swagger))
                .license(buildLicense(swagger)));
        openAPI.externalDocs(buildExternalDocs(swagger));
        openAPI.components(buildComponents(swagger));
        return openAPI;
    }

    /**
     * Get the Swagger app info with defaults if not populated
     *
     * @return The swagger app
     */
    private ExodusConfigSwaggerApp setDefaults() {
        ExodusConfig config = Optional.ofNullable(exodusConfig).orElse(new ExodusConfig());
        ExodusConfigSwagger swagger = Optional.of(config).map(ExodusConfig::getSwagger).orElse(new ExodusConfigSwagger());
        ExodusConfigSwaggerApp app = Optional.of(swagger).map(ExodusConfigSwagger::getApp).orElse(new ExodusConfigSwaggerApp());
        app.setName(setOrDefault(app.getName(), "default"));
        app.setVersion(setOrDefault(app.getVersion(), "unknown"));
        app.setApm(setOrDefault(app.getApm(), "unknown"));
        app.setPorttype(setOrDefault(app.getPorttype(), "unknown"));
        app.setServicekey(setOrDefault(app.getServicekey(), "unknown"));
        app.setDescription(setOrDefault(app.getDescription(), "default"));
        app.setVendor(setOrDefault(app.getVendor(), "default"));
        app.setContactEmail(setOrDefault(app.getContactEmail(), "default"));
        app.setContactName(setOrDefault(app.getContactName(), "default"));
        app.setContacturl(setOrDefault(app.getContacturl(), "default"));
        app.setConfluencePage(setOrDefault(app.getConfluencePage(), "default"));
        app.setAuthorizationType(setOrDefault(app.getAuthorizationType(), "Bearer"));
        return app;
    }

    /**
     * Set the string if it has value to value or else default
     *
     * @param value        The value to set if not blank
     * @param defaultValue The default
     *
     * @return The value if not empty or default
     */
    private String setOrDefault(String value, String defaultValue) {
        return Optional.ofNullable(value)
                .filter(StringUtils::isNotBlank)
                .orElse(defaultValue);
    }

}

And while I can understand if this is overkill on the break outs. The problem is when I try to go to:

http://localhost:8080/swagger-ui.html

I see it redirects to:

http://localhost:8080/swagger-ui/index.html?configUrl=/v3/api-docs/swagger-config

But then I get the following:

{"timestamp":"2023-09-13T17:02:04.695+00:00","status":404,"error":"Not Found","message":"No message available","path":"/swagger-ui/index.html"}

And I am not sure what I am doing wrong.

Would be simpler just returning the single field `studentName`.

items.title: Function in PostgreSQL returns null with "out" value
items.body:
I'm using a Java EE to do some queries and check how they work with PostgreSQL functions, but its always returns null when the parameter type is "out".

create function updateStudent (inout studentId int, out studentName varchar(15))
language plpgsql as $$
    begin
        select name into studentName from students where id = studentId;
        update students set name = studentName where id = studentId;
    end;
$$

public class Testing {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        EntityManagerFactory emf = Persistence
                .createEntityManagerFactory("studentUnit");

        EntityManager manager = emf.createEntityManager();
        manager.getTransaction().begin();
        StoredProcedureQuery query = manager
                .createStoredProcedureQuery("updateStudent");
        query.registerStoredProcedureParameter("studentId", Integer.class, ParameterMode.INOUT);
        query.registerStoredProcedureParameter("studentName", String.class, ParameterMode.OUT);
        query.setParameter("studentId", 1);
        query.execute();
        System.out.println(query.getOutputParameterValue("studentName"));
        manager.getTransaction().commit();

        emf.close();
    }
}

answers.body_markdown: You can have many constructors as long as they take in different parameters.  But the compiler putting a default constructor in is not called "constructor overriding".
answers.title: Is Constructor Overriding Possible?
answers.body: You can have many constructors as long as they take in different parameters. But the compiler putting a default constructor in is not called "constructor overriding".

answers.body_markdown: Your example is not an override. Overrides technically occur in a subclass, but in this example the contructor method is replaced in the original class.
answers.title: Is Constructor Overriding Possible?
answers.body: Your example is not an override. Overrides technically occur in a subclass, but in this example the contructor method is replaced in the original class.

answers.body_markdown:
Cannot override constructor. Constructor can be regarded as static, subclass cannot override its super constructor.

Of course, you could call protected-method in super class constructor, then overide it in subclass to change super class constructor. However, many persons suggest not to use the trick, in order to protect super class constructor behavior. For instance, FindBugs will warn you that a constructor calls a non-final method.
answers.title: Is Constructor Overriding Possible?
answers.body:
Cannot override constructor. Constructor can be regarded as static, subclass cannot override its super constructor.

Of course, you could call protected-method in super class constructor, then overide it in subclass to change super class constructor. However, many persons suggest not to use the trick, in order to protect super class constructor behavior. For instance, FindBugs will warn you that a constructor calls a non-final method.

answers.body_markdown:
Constructors are not normal methods and they cannot be "overridden". Saying that a constructor can be overridden would imply that a superclass constructor would be visible and could be called to create an instance of a subclass. This isn't true... a subclass doesn't have any constructors by default (except a no-arg constructor _if_ the class it extends has one). It has to explicitly declare any other constructors, and those constructors belong to it and not to its superclass, even if they take the same parameters that the superclass constructors take.

The stuff you mention about default no arg constructors is just an aspect of how constructors work and has nothing to do with overriding.
answers.title: Is Constructor Overriding Possible?
answers.body:
Constructors are not normal methods and they cannot be "overridden". Saying that a constructor can be overridden would imply that a superclass constructor would be visible and could be called to create an instance of a subclass. This isn't true... a subclass doesn't have any constructors by default (except a no-arg constructor if the class it extends has one). It has to explicitly declare any other constructors, and those constructors belong to it and not to its superclass, even if they take the same parameters that the superclass constructors take.

The stuff you mention about default no arg constructors is just an aspect of how constructors work and has nothing to do with overriding.

answers.body_markdown:
What you describe isn't overriding. If you don't specify a default constructor, the
compiler will create a default constructor. If it's a subclass, it will call 
the default parent constructor([super()][1]), it will also initialize all instance variables to
a default value determined by the type's default value(0 for numeric types, false for booleans, or null
for objects).

Overriding happens when a subclass has the same name, number/type of parameters, and
the same return type as an instance method of the superclass. In this case, the subclass
will *override* the superclass's method. [Information on overriding here][2].


  [1]: http://www.leepoint.net/notes-java/oop/constructors/constructor-super.html
  [2]: http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/IandI/override.html
answers.title: Is Constructor Overriding Possible?
answers.body:
What you describe isn't overriding. If you don't specify a default constructor, the compiler will create a default constructor. If it's a subclass, it will call the default parent constructor(super()), it will also initialize all instance variables to a default value determined by the type's default value(0 for numeric types, false for booleans, or null for objects).

Overriding happens when a subclass has the same name, number/type of parameters, and the same return type as an instance method of the superclass. In this case, the subclass will override the superclass's method. Information on overriding here.

answers.body_markdown:
> But if we write it ourselves, that
> constructor is called automatically.

That's not correct. The no-args constructor is called *if you call it,* and regardless of whether or not you wrote it yourself. It is also called automatically if you don't code an explicit super(...) call in a derived class.

None of this constitutes constructor overriding. There is no such thing in Java.
There *is* constructor *overloading,* i.e. providing different argument sets.
answers.title: Is Constructor Overriding Possible?
answers.body:
But if we write it ourselves, that constructor is called automatically.

That's not correct. The no-args constructor is called if you call it, and regardless of whether or not you wrote it yourself. It is also called automatically if you don't code an explicit super(...) call in a derived class.

None of this constitutes constructor overriding. There is no such thing in Java. There is constructor overloading, i.e. providing different argument sets.

answers.body_markdown:
It is never possible. Constructor Overriding is never possible in Java.   

This is because, 

> Constructor looks like a method but
> name should be as class name and no
> return value.
> 
> Overriding means what we have declared
> in Super class, that exactly we have
> to declare in Sub class it is called
> Overriding. Super class name and Sub
> class names are different.
> 
> If you trying to write Super class
> Constructor in Sub class, then Sub
> class will treat that as a method not
> constructor because name should
> not match with Sub class name. And it
> will give an compilation error that
> methods does not have return value. So
> we should declare as void, then only
> it will compile.  


----------


Have a look at the following code :  

    Class One
            {
             ....
             One() { // Super Class constructor
              .... 
            }
    
            One(int a) { // Super Class Constructor Overloading
              .... 
            }
     }
    
    Class Two extends One
                       {
                        One() {    // this is a method not constructor 
                        .....      // because name should not match with Class name
                       }
    
                        Two() { // sub class constructor
                       ....  
                       }
    
                       Two(int b) { // sub class constructor overloading
                       ....
                      }
     }
answers.title: Is Constructor Overriding Possible?
answers.body:
It is never possible. Constructor Overriding is never possible in Java.

This is because,

Constructor looks like a method but name should be as class name and no return value.

Overriding means what we have declared in Super class, that exactly we have to declare in Sub class it is called Overriding. Super class name and Sub class names are different.

If you trying to write Super class Constructor in Sub class, then Sub class will treat that as a method not constructor because name should not match with Sub class name. And it will give an compilation error that methods does not have return value. So we should declare as void, then only it will compile.

Have a look at the following code : 

Class One
        {
         ....
         One() { // Super Class constructor
          .... 
        }

        One(int a) { // Super Class Constructor Overloading
          .... 
        }
 }

Class Two extends One
                   {
                    One() {    // this is a method not constructor 
                    .....      // because name should not match with Class name
                   }

                    Two() { // sub class constructor
                   ....  
                   }

                   Two(int b) { // sub class constructor overloading
                   ....
                  }
 }

answers.body_markdown: Because a constructor cannot be inherited in Java and Method Overriding requires inheritance. Therefore, it's not applicable.
answers.title: Is Constructor Overriding Possible?
answers.body: Because a constructor cannot be inherited in Java and Method Overriding requires inheritance. Therefore, it's not applicable.

answers.body_markdown:
Constructor overriding is not possible because of following reason.

Constructor name must be the same name of class name. In Inheritance practice you need to create two classes with different names hence two constructors must have different names. So constructor overriding is not possible and that thought not even make sense.

Constructor overriding is not possible because of following reason.

Constructor name must be the same name of class name. In Inheritance practice you need to create two classes with different names hence two constructors must have different names. So constructor overriding is not possible and that thought not even make sense.

items.body_markdown: What I know is: the compiler writes a default no-argument constructor in the byte code. But if we write it ourselves, that constructor is called automatically. Is this phenomenon constructor overriding?
